race.name: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder
race.tagline: State park forest roads through rural Clearfield County, Pennsylvania.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Pennsylvania countryside. Moderate elevation with rolling scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Local Pennsylvania event. Rolling terrain with remote access, low costs, and small local field.

biased_opinion.summary: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder is a local event in Pennsylvaniaâ€”rolling terrain with moderate elevation. The Pennsylvania countryside is nice and it's good value, but the small local field, remote location, and limited organization keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid local Pennsylvania gravel race. Worth it for Pennsylvania/Northeast riders. Not worth traveling for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to Pennsylvaniaâ€”yes, it's good value. If you're travelingâ€”skip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better Pennsylvania races: Dirty Kanza PA, Trans-Sylvania Epic.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Clearfield County has limited lodging options. Plan ahead.
logistics.food: Clearfield County has limited dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Parker Dam Gravel Grinder website

course_description.ridewithgps_name: Parker Dam Gravel Grinder - Half Series Route 2024

non_negotiables.why: Pennsylvania rolling terrain requires sustained effort.
Limited organization and remote location require self-sufficiency.

logistics.explanation: S.B. Elliott State Park provides established venue infrastructure with 7:00 AM registration for 9:00 AM start - tight 90-minute window. Lynn Botelho noted she "remembered to make sure my hydration pack was actually functioning this time," suggesting prep logistics matter more than venue amenities in rural Penfield, PA.

length.explanation: The 52-mile half series sits in comfortable middle ground territory. Lynn Botelho set "a fairly high pace early" knowing she could sustain it over the distance, getting caught by a faster rider at mile 30 who helped her "ride faster" through drafting - manageable length for strategic racing. More compact than Grinduro.

technicality.explanation: Course described as "relatively flat course for this part of the world" by Pennsylvania standards, mixing gravel roads with paved sections. Lynn Botelho noted she "descend like a demon," using technical descending skills to pass riders, suggesting moderate technical demands without extreme challenges. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: 3,500 feet over 50 miles means steady climbing without massive punches - 70 feet per mile average. The full 72-mile route hits 5,707 feet, so you're getting Pennsylvania's rolling terrain. Respectable but not mountainous. Less climbing than The Mid South. As Lynn Botelho puts it: "I remain thankful that I descend like a demon. ðŸ˜‰ However, the race ends with about a 12-mile hill, and my goal here was to 'just be tired tomorrow' and do the work now."

climate.explanation: May 9th date in Pennsylvania means spring weather variability - could be 45 and rainy or 75 and perfect. No historical weather data available for this specific event. Standard Northeast spring gamble. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Clearfield County, Pennsylvania sits well below 2,000 feet elevation. Zero altitude considerations - pure power and fitness race without thin air factors affecting performance. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds â€” no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Rural Pennsylvania gravel roads through state park lands offer decent scenery without epic wilderness. Course features aren't documented, suggesting standard gravel road network. Pleasant countryside riding without destination-race adventure factor.

prestige.explanation: This is the 6th annual edition of a Pennsylvania Gravel Series race in Penfield, PA. No notable past winners documented, no pro field data, no YouTube coverage. It's a regional series race that hasn't broken into the national conversation.

race_quality.explanation: Trans-Sylvania Productions delivers chip timing, well-marked course, and fully stocked aid stations with reasonable cutoffs. Limited to 300 participants with organized registration system - solid execution of basic gravel race infrastructure without standout operational features.

experience.explanation: You get an event shirt, post-race meal, and awards for top 3 finishers in each category. S.B. Elliott State Park provides a decent venue, but no unique course features are documented. Solid small-town gravel race experience without memorable elements. As Mark Loux puts it: "The gravel is mostly hard packed and there was very little loose gravel sections. We had two double track sections that could be muddier than what we experienced."

community.explanation: Part of the Pennsylvania Gravel Series as Race #2, which creates some regional continuity. Visit Clearfield County sponsors it, suggesting local support.

field_depth.explanation: Field size data completely unavailable, no mention of competitive riders or pro participation. Being a small Pennsylvania town race in its 6th year without documented fast fields suggests limited depth. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder. As Lynn Botelho puts it: "This is a relatively flat course for this part of the world, I decided to try setting a fairly high (for me) pace and to hold it throughout the race."

value.explanation: Registration includes shirt, chip timing, post-race meal, aid stations, and awards - solid package for what's likely modest entry fees. Three distance options (23, 52, or 72 miles) give flexibility. Early bird pricing with only $10 increase shows reasonable fee structure.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $50-75. Penfield, PA keeps lodging and dining costs reasonable compared to destination races. Visit Clearfield County sponsorship suggests local accommodation options exist - rural Pennsylvania location controls expenses though specific pricing data unavailable. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners
